subject: Re: [junit] awkward mocking options.

messageBody:
Hi JB!

Not sure if group feels that this is Junit related question.. Please
excuse if it is not..

Wanted to know how Unit Testing would change with wide adoption of
aspectJ features, specially w.r.t to mocking some object to test a
dependent classes. Any papers in this direction is well appreciated.

Regards,
Nagendra


J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Kevin O'Sullivan wrote:
>
> > Hi -
> >
> > I am modifying code in an existing app. I have changed code a private
> > method, and I'm trying to write a junit test case (the first on this
> proj)
> > to validate this. (see pseudo code below)
> >
> > The problem is with the call to the static class ServiceLocator to
> get the
> > 'client' object. Normally I would just mock this to client obj to do
> > nothing, as I don't care a jot about it in my test case. (I need to
> mock it
> > because it makes calls to a web service). Because its instantiated
> inside
> > the method, I can't see any simple way to mock the client object.
>
> Try jMock with the CGLib stuff. That way you can substitute a mock
> version of ServiceLocator.getOrgMgrServiceClient() which returns your
> own (mock) ServiceClient implementation.
>
> I only recommend this because you claim you can't change the code that
> invokes the ServiceLocator, and I have learned through trial and error
> not to argue with someone who claims that. :) This is an area where a
> design change is needed, and with luck, sometime in the future, you can
> make that happen.
